heading: bulk buying comes to the web
subheading: the more people who want something, the higher the price, right? maybe not. a new web shop called accompany flips the supply-demand equation on its head. by craig bicknell.
author: craig bicknell
text: normally, when thousands of people get a hankering to buy the exact same thing at the exact same time, the price of the item goes way, way up. see furby. a new web retailer called accompany hopes to flip things around. the company believes it can get huge volume discounts from manufacturers by aggregating online shoppers' orders into one huge purchase. the bigger the order, the higher the discount."for other web businesses like auction sites, the question is, how do you get people to compete to drive up price?" said jim rose, accompany's ceo. "for us, the question is, how do you get people to cooperate to drive down price and improve service?"the company launched tuesday. it began by taking orders for 3com's palm v handheld computer.here's how it works. throughout a 12-hour "buy cycle," consumers place credit-card orders for the palms, which start out at the regular retail price. as more and more people order, the price begins to drop. accompany aggregates the orders until the end of the cycle, then places a bulk order.ordering in bulk allows customers to get the sort of cut-rate deal normally reserved for corporate customers who buy in big volume. everyone who orders gets the goods for the lower price.accompany keeps an order tally on its site, and tells customers how many more orders are needed to bump the price down to the next bulk-pricing notch. accompany hopes that will motivate its customers to send bargain-hunting friends, family, and coworkers to the site during each buy cycle."you have a direct incentive to get everyone else involved," said rose.accompany plans to start slowly, introducing one or two consumer electronic and software products a day for the next few weeks. ultimately, it hopes to offer an array of tech goodies, supplied by individual manufacturers and wholesale distribution giant tech data.
